header.aside: Meet Christina Hallalulu, author and founder of the recipe blog, Lila,Chop! Clandestine Health food and Living... fatally delicious, baking clean with protein powder and her Siberian Husky Lila, the muse behind the name.

section.p: My name is Christina, and Delila-Sky (aka Lila) is my Siberian Husky and muse behind the name, Lila, Chop! I am half-Thai, half-Swedish, and passionate about everything related to fitness, health, gourmet food, travel and Siberian huskies. I am also a pilot, and I love to fly.
But let's talk about my love of healthy gourmet food–a supposed oxymoron.

figure.figcaption: Hardly able to wait to dig into this freshly-grilled lobster

section.p: Having graduated last year from the world's top hotel school, Ecole h√¥teliere de Lausanne in Switzerland, I suddenly found myself with a lot of time on my hands and the usual pressing decisions to make about what to do with life, career, identiy, et cetera. I certainly didn't feel ready to open up my own hotel or start my own chain of restaurants, nor did I feel inclined to work split shifts as a chef. But there had to be something I could do with my background and food! Something non-traditional, something that would reflect my personal journey and beliefs.

figure.figcaption: Injured and posing in my EHL kitchen uniform

section.p: Raised as a pesce-vegetarian, and having spent the better part of my teens and early twenties yo-yo-dieting and obsessively experimenting with different food regimens (vegan, vegetarian, gluten-free, raw food, macrobiotic and detox fasts) I was fundamentally fed up of dieting and restricting myself.

I have always been a real foodie and known for my sweet tooth –some of my favourite childhood memories include trying out Argentinean snow fish at one of Bangkok's top Italian restaurants and baking Swedish cinnamon buns (kanelbullar) with my grandmother in Gothenburg.

I love gastronomy, fine-dining, luxury ingredients such as white truffle and lobster, and gourmet-cooking at home.
I will admit a secret here: I have a terrible sweet tooth.
My favourite desserts in the world include molten chocolate (molleaux au chocolat) and sticky toffee pudding (how much unhealthier can one's tastes get?).
I love visiting chocolate atelieres and sampling the richest hand-made truffles creations of the day, and buying the finest ingredients to bring back home to use in my baking.

img.alt: Christina and Lila in a Chocolate factory

figure.figcaption: Me and Lila in a Chocolate Factory in Gruyeres, Switzerland.

section.p:
Spending four-years at the most renown hotel school in the world did nothing but cultivate and refine my taste and interest in this.
Furthermore, kitchen practicals gave me ample opportunity to refine my baking skills, such as making Swedish sticky chocolate cake (kladdkaka) one of the most notoriously sinfully delicious and unhealthy desserts out there, in large quantities.

img.alt: Christina baking Swedish sticky chocolate cake

figure.figcaption: Baking Swedish sticky chocolate cake, in gigantic proportions

section.p: But I had a problem–I could not coincide this with my passion for health and fitness, with my female pride of wanting to look good in a bikini, and my sound belief in taking care of one's body by nourishing it with wholesome, lean and natural foods.

img.alt: Christina in a bikini and eating dessert and fruit.

figure.figcaption: Unable to choose between the healthy fruit plate and the dessert plate... I'll have both.

section.p:
That was the perpetual conflict: being a real foodie, but also a real health junkie.
Above all, after years of illness and general ill-treatment of my own body, I was just starting to heal physically.
For the first time in my life, I was hitting the gym regularly, and hard.
Six days a week, two hours a day–weights, and adding more strength-training to my previously card-dominant workouts along with high intensity interval training.
I began to find myself in the best shape of my life, and getting continually stronger, fitter, and leaner every month.

This could only have been possible with the right approach to food and nutrition, however.
Without wanting to restrict myself and stubbornly refusing to get sucked back into any diet mentality, I had to learn how to eat properly for this intensity of workouts, lifestyle and fitness goals.
Sadly, there seemed to be no room for a gourmet foodie in this picture–boring cottage-cheese salads, egg-white omelettes, cardboard-tasting protein bars and grainy, protein shakes!
(And every time such dire thoughts crossed my mind, I would find myself inexplicably fantasising about ice cream.)

img.alt: Christina eat all the ice cream

figure.figcaption: Huck eat all the ice cream!

section.p:
Fortunately, I found a way around that –the perfect compromise between fine food and fine health: clean cooking and baking.
By clean, I mean using natural, whole, organic, predominantly-unprocessed ingredients. Ingredients low in sugar, fat, gluten and lactose.
Thanks to Instagram, I found hundreds of recipe ideas from fellow health-foodies, and tips from fitness models on how to make decadent, protein-rich desserts worthy of the names pre- or post-workout meal.
By protein-rich, I mean incorporating protein powder into the actual recipes themselves. In fact, I learned that the one major secret ingredient was baking with protein powder. I call this the sex appeal behind my healthy creations, because it's the one ingredient that spiffies up my creations in terms of consistency, flavour, sweetness and nutritional value.

figure.figcaption: Success of the healthy girl's brunch chez-moi

section.p:
I began experimenting, and inviting my girlfriends over for Sunday brunch to taste out my clean, healthy and protein-filled creations.
Everything from two-layered frozen smoothies to protein pancakes to home-made protein bars and cheesecake... it was incredible. I realised I was good at it. I loved making it, and they loved trying it. Pretty soon all my friends were asking me for my recipes, and I could not keep up with scribbling them down on post-its or writing them in the Instagram comments of my photos.

One day, someone very special to me called K, decided to help me finally start my own blog.
Being the most regular sampler of all my recipes, he knew more about my protein creations and the process behind them than anyone else.
Wracking our minds for a suitable name (the protein bakery seemed too generic) he was inspired by my beloved Lila, the travelling husky and cat-connoisseur. The dog who is known for her refined tastes and response to the Chop! command, and who can be expected to make a sudden appearance in the kitchen when I'm baking, deserves to name my online cafe and recipe collection.
Thus, Lila, Chop! was born. The online cafe and recipe blog that promises Clandestine Health food and Living. Fatally delicious, baking clean with protein powder.

As you are reading this site, you are obviously interested in healthy food and delicious recipes. You may be a gourmet-foodie, a health-food junkie, or a fitness-addict. You may be on a restrictive diet due to food intolerances and struggling to find ways to make bread and desserts that don't taste like sandpaper, or your average, health-conscious person interested in ways to increase your protein-intake in a delicious way.

My promise to you with Lila, Chop! is that ALL the ingredients I use are healthy, clean and wholesome. I link the products I use to the websites I bought them from, so you can buy them online yourselves. (all the products I mention are ones I choose to use because I personally find them of high-quality, suitable for my recipes and generally yummy.) Most of the recipes I make are gluten- and lactose-free, and almost all of them are high in protein. Check out the nutritional information and the food-icons to see exactly what kind of nutritional profile each recipe has! And remember, you can always adapt them to your liking. If you choose to post photos of your creations from my recipes or to repost the recipes themselves, be sure to cite me! Likewise, I make sure to cite all the recipes I adapt and find inspiration from. Happy baking, and namnam.
